session.name: Liberty Index 2025 - U.S. House
session.description: Created by the Republican Liberty Caucus, the 2025 Liberty Index is a liberty-focused legislative scorecard for the U.S. House. The Liberty Index scores Republican members of Congress on 20 pivotal bills/votes from the 119th Congress that either advance liberty or diminish liberty.

bills.title: The Nutria Eradication and Control Reauthorization Act, which reauthorizes through 2030 the Department of Interior to provide financial assistance to states to eradicate/control nutrial (invasive rode
bills.description: The Nutria Eradication and Control Reauthorization Act, which reauthorizes through 2030 the Department of Interior to provide financial assistance to states to eradicate/control nutrial (invasive rodents) and restore marshalnd damaged by nutria. This issue should be left up to the states. With $38 trillion of debt, the federal government cannot afford this.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 361-56 on 2/4/25, Held in Senate

bills.title: The Protecting American Energy Production Act, which prohibits any U
bills.description: The Protecting American Energy Production Act, which prohibits any U.S. President from declaring a moratorium on hydraulic fracturing (fracking) without authorization from Congress. The bill also states that fracking should be left up to the states to regulate. H.R. 26 safeguards free enterprise while preventing the executive branch from side stepping Congress.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 226-188 on 2/7/25, Held in Senate

bills.title: This joint resolution nullifies an EPA rule from 2024 which imposed a fee/tax on methane and other emmissions from the oil/gas industry
bills.description: This joint resolution nullifies an EPA rule from 2024 which imposed a fee/tax on methane and other emmissions from the oil/gas industry. H.J.Res 35 is a good bill to repeal an unnecessary tax.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 220-206 on 2/26/25, Passed Senate 52-47 on 2/27/25, Signed by President

bills.title: This joint resolution nullifies a rule imposed by the Department of Energy in 2024 which imposed onerous requirements on gas-fired water heaters, essentially banning them
bills.description: This joint resolution nullifies a rule imposed by the Department of Energy in 2024 which imposed onerous requirements on gas-fired water heaters, essentially banning them. H.J. Res. 20 is a good bill to restore economic freedom by repealing unnecessary and excessive regulations.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 221-198 on 2/27/25, Passed Senate 53-44 on 4/10/25, Signed by President

bills.title: The Full-Year Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, which approves $1
bills.description: The Full-Year Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, which approves $1.6 trillion in spending, funding the federal government from March 15, 2025 through September 30, 2025. This bill continues funding the federal government at the same levels approved by President Biden during the prior year. With a $38 trillion debt, this bloated spending bill is irresponsible and reckless.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 217-213 on 3/11/25, Passed Senate 54-46 on 3/14/25, Signed by President

bills.title: The IMPACT Act, which requires the Department of Energy to fund a new Research and Development program focused on reducing emmissions from asphalt and conrete production
bills.description: The IMPACT Act, which requires the Department of Energy to fund a new Research and Development program focused on reducing emmissions from asphalt and conrete production. With a $38 trillion debt, it is fiscally irresponsible to expand the scope of the Department of Energy.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 350-73 on 3/25/25, Held in Senate

bills.title: The Setting Consumer Standards for Lithium-Ion Batteries Act, which imposes new regulations (consumer standards) on Lithium-Ion Batteries
bills.description: The Setting Consumer Standards for Lithium-Ion Batteries Act, which imposes new regulations (consumer standards) on Lithium-Ion Batteries. This bill was drafted with good intentions: to improve battery safety. However, instead of creating more federal regulations, this issue should be left to the free market.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 365-42 on 4/28/25, Held in Senate

bills.title: The TICKET Act, which imposes new regulations on event ticket sales
bills.description: The TICKET Act, which imposes new regulations on event ticket sales. This bill was drafted with good intentions: to offer transparency for ticket buyers. However, instead of creating more federal regulations, this issue should be left to the free market.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 409-15 on 4/29/25, Held in Senate

bills.title: This joint resolution nullifies an EPA waiver that allowed California to mandate the sale of zero-emmission trucks
bills.description: This joint resolution nullifies an EPA waiver that allowed California to mandate the sale of zero-emmission trucks. In short, H.J. Res. 87 repealed California's mandate that required car manufacturers to sell zero-emmission trucks.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 231-191 on 4/30/25, Passed Senate 51-45 on 5/22/25, Signed by President

bills.title: The Rescissions Act of 2025, which rescinds $9
bills.description: The Rescissions Act of 2025, which rescinds $9.4 billion in federal funding for various agencies, including the Department of State, Corporation for Public Broadcasting, and the US Agency for International Development. H.R. 4 is a good bill that cuts wasteful, unnecessary spending.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 214-212 on 6/12/25, Passed Senate 51-48 on 7/17/25, Signed by President

bills.title: H
bills.description: H.R. 1 appropriates $320 billion in new spending, while increasing the debt ceiling by $5 trillion. It increases the budget deficit by $270 billion. The bill does do some good things: it extends the 2017 tax cuts, increases certain tax deductions and eliminates taxes on tips and overtime. While we support tax cuts, overrall, this legsilation is fiscally ierresponsible. It significantly increases the size of the federal government while further adding to the $38 trillion national debt.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 218-214 on 7/3/25, Passed Senate 51-50 on 7/1/25, Signed by President

bills.title: The Department of Defense Appropriations Act, which appropriates $831
bills.description: The Department of Defense Appropriations Act, which appropriates $831.5 billion for the Department of Defense budget for FY2026. This pushes total 2026 military spending above $1 trillion, a 13% increase from the prior year. While we support a strong military, it is fiscally irresponsible to give this much taxpayer money to a department that has failed its audit eight years in a row, especially when factoring in the $38 trillion national debt.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 221-209 on 7/18/25, Senate Cloture Motion Failed 50-44 on 10/16/25

bills.title: The Greene Amendment #93 to H
bills.description: The Greene Amendment #93 to H.R. 3838 would have prohibited further foreign aid to Ukraine, while cutting $500 million in aid to Israel.

bills.title: The first version of the 2025 National Defense Authorization Act
bills.description: The first version of the 2025 National Defense Authorization Act. This 1,300 page bill appropriates $884.3 billion in militiary spending for FY2026. The bill appropriates over $2 billion in foreign aid: $1 billion to Taiwan, $800 million to Ukraine, $700 million for Israel, and $175 to Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. While we support a strong military, it is fiscally irresponsible to give this much taxpayer money to a department that has failed its audit eight years in a row, especially when factoring in the $38 trillion national debt.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 231-196 on 9/10/25, Held in Senate

bills.title: The Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, which funds the federal government from November 12th, 2025 through January 30th, 2026, at the same spending levels approved by President Biden during
bills.description: The Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, which funds the federal government from November 12th, 2025 through January 30th, 2026, at the same spending levels approved by President Biden during the prior year. The bill also includes a full year of funding for the Department of Agriculture, the FDA, the Department of Veterans Affairs, and Congress. The bill also bans hemp nationwide and allows eight Senators to seek up to $500,000 in damages from the government accessing their phone records. With a $38 trillion debt, this bloated spending bill is irresponsible and reckless.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 222-209 on 11/12/25, Passed Senate 60-40 on 11/10/25, Signed by President

bills.title: The Epstein Files Transparency Act, which orders the Department of Justice to publish all the Epstein Files within 30 days of its passage
bills.description: The Epstein Files Transparency Act, which orders the Department of Justice to publish all the Epstein Files within 30 days of its passage.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 427-1 on 11/18/25, Passed Senate 100-0 on 11/18/25, Signed by President

bills.title: The final version of the 2025 National Defense Authorization Act
bills.description: The final version of the 2025 National Defense Authorization Act. This 3,086 page bill appropriates $900.6 billion in military spending for FY2026, which is $8 billion more than the Presidentâ€™s budget request. Adding to the $156 billion previously allocated in H.R. 1, this pushes the defense budget over $1 trillion; over $100 billion more than the previous year. The bill allocates an extensive amount of foreign aid: $1 billion for Taiwan, $2.5 billion for the Philippines, $685 million for Israel, $800 million for Ukraine, and $175 million for Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania. While we support a strong military, it is fiscally irresponsible to give this much taxpayer money to a department that has failed its audit eight years in a row, especially when factoring in the $38 trillion national debt.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 312-212 on 12/10/25, Passed Senate 77-20 on 12/17/25, Signed by President

bills.title: This concurrent resolution directs the President to remove U
bills.description: This concurrent resolution directs the President to remove U.S. Armed Forces from hostilities within or against Venezuela unless a declaration of war or authorization to use military force has been enacted.
bills.vote_result_summary: Failed House 211-213 on 12/17/25

bills.title: The Lower Health Care Premiums for All Americans Act, which expands access to association health plans and creates a tax credit for small businesses
bills.description: The Lower Health Care Premiums for All Americans Act, which expands access to association health plans and creates a tax credit for small businesses. This bill reduces government mandates and increases economic freedom, allowing more affordable options for health insurance; especially for those employed by small businesses. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the bill will reduce the deficit by $35.6 million.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 216-211 on 12/17/25, Held in Senate

bills.title: The SPEED Act, which speeds up the federal permitting process required before building infrastructure, energy, and mining projects
bills.description: The SPEED Act, which speeds up the federal permitting process required before building infrastructure, energy, and mining projects. Specifically, the bill curbs some environmental regulations and shortens the permitting process, allowing these projects to move along faster.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 221-196 on 12/18/25, Held in Senate

bills.title: The National Constitutional Carry Act, which would allow law abiding citizens to carry their firearm(s) regardless of which state they are in
bills.description: The National Constitutional Carry Act, which would allow law abiding citizens to carry their firearm(s) regardless of which state they are in.

bills.title: The Federal Reserve Transparency Act, which would audit the Federal Reserve
bills.description: The Federal Reserve Transparency Act, which would audit the Federal Reserve.
